cells.source: The top 5 toiler paper brands all make 1 billion + dollars a year. And of the top 10 brands, they can be consolidated to 3 companies. _Georgia pacific LLC_ which owns **private label, angel soft, and quilted northern ultra strong**. Two of which make above a billion dollars a year. _Procter Gamble_ which owns **Charmin ultra soft and strong**, again both making above a billion dollars a year in revenue. _Kimberly clark corporation_ owns **Scott technologies**, **Kleenex Cottonelle Clean Care, Kleenex Cottonelle Ultra Comfort Care, Scott Extra Soft.**
As we can see from this info graphic, 31 million trees are cut down every year to supply the us with toilet paper. A YEAR. To put this into comparison:

Side node, I was going to compare the the amount of trees used to make pencils, but it seems there is not a really good number to put on this. If you look this up youll see a stat which states that 82k trees are used to make 14 billion pencils a year. Which sounds wildly innacurate and when I went to go look as to where this figure originates from. I found that its from a website called "something wonderful" where someone around 2009 says the above fact and it seems websites have just taken this and ran with it. In an article by [rediff ](https://www.rediff.com/getahead/report/achievers-meet-indian-superheroes-vishnu-vardhan-divya-shetty-plantcil-eco-friendly-pencils/20180309.htm)where they interview some Vishnu Vardhan and Divya Shetty, co-founders of Indian Superheroes.

__

_""Over 13 million hectares of forest is lost to deforestation, of which, 36 per cent is for paper manufacturing and 42 per cent for manufacturing timber-based products that constitutes 18-20 billion pencils," says Vardhan.These statistics were enough to make Vardhan and Shetty ponder over the use of recycled paper to make pencils. "We decided to mitigate two evils at once and that's how Plantcil was born," says Vardhan. ""_


This article also does not site their sources and I cant find where Vishnu or Divya found this figure.

Even with both the, wildly, conservative estimation of 82k trees or the liberal 8 million trees a year. We are still using almost double that amount of trees. The case becomes even worse when we delve into water usage.
### --Toilet paper water usage

In an Article by [bioBidet  ](https://biobidet.com/blogs/news/is-toilet-paper-sustainable-the-toilet-paper-problem) they state that a single roll of toilet paper can take up to 37 gallons of water to produce. If we do some quick math

#how much toilet paper one tree makes
one_tree = 1500
#total number of tress consumed by toilet paper production a year
total_tress = 31114249
#number of gallons used to make 1 toiler paper roll
water_used = 37
print((one_tree * total_tress)*37)

Okay, I guess not, when trying to run this I was told I was out of memory.  it should say 1726840819500 gallons of water to produce our toilet paper.  Of course this is from a pro bidet website so I found another article from [Scientific America](https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/earth-talks-bidets/) stating:



_"because they eliminate the use of toilet paper. According to his analysis, Americans use 36.5 billion rolls of toilet paper every year, representing the pulping of some 15 million trees. Says Thomas: “This also involves 473,587,500,000 gallons of water to produce the paper and 253,000 tons of chlorine for bleaching."_


Doing some reverse engineering:

#how much toilet paper is used by the us according to scientifc america
Toilet_paper_usage = 36500000000
#how much water is used in this process acording to scientific america
Total_water_usage = 47358750000
print(Total_water_usage/Toilet_paper_usage)
We get 1.2 gallons of water used per toilet paper roll. Wildly varied from bio bidet. However, we can still take these two ranges as a conservative and liberal estimate.
### How much water does a bidet use?

Its a little tricky to pin point.



In the same article by bio bidet, they state that a bidet uses 1/8th of a gallon per use. In the [link](https://biobidet.com/blogs/news/do-bidets-waste-water) which they site this claim, it leads us to another article written by them it says that a bidet uses the same amount of water as you would use when washing your hands.  In a statement released by the [EPA](https://www.epa.gov/watersense/bathroom-faucets) says that a standard faucet uses 2.2 gallons of water per minute. Taking the 20 second recommended washing time we can get that

# number of gallons used
Gallon_used = 2.2
# fraction of time it takes to wash hands
Time_spent = 1 / 3
print(Gallon_used * Time_spent)

Giving us an estimate of 3/4ths of a gallon per usage based off of the epa faucet estimate and also the statement made by bio bidet. 

So how much water is this per year?

Well, we will have to do some rough estimations.

How often do people poop? 

In an article titled [Assessment of normal bowel habits in the general adult population: the Popcol study ](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/20205503/)they saw that 98% of their participants pooped between 3 times a day to 3 times per week. 

If we take this massive generelization for the whole of the united states. So, if we take the population of the united states, being 334,233,854 as of 2022 based on the census.

On a low range we get that americans poop 52140481224 times a year, and on the high end; 365986070130


this would then equate to

(am I doing this wrong? im kind of dumbfounded by the fact that doing this calculation makes my kernal run out of memory??)

On the low range we would use 39105360918 gallons of water per year or 274489552597.5 on the high end. No small amount of water to scoff at by any means, but on the high end almost 100 billion gallons less than toilet paper!
# Conclusion

There are demonstrable benefits to switching to bidets for the environment. Even the most exacerbated estimates, we are saving billions of gallons of water and millions of millions of trees.  The answer is clear and absolute.
